Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang of the Great Tang Dynasty on Imperial Order
Chapter 2, Section 3: The Two Dharmas
I heard these words from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
There are two kinds of giving.
What are the two?
First, material giving;
Second, giving of the Dharma.
What is material giving?

It refers to a type of person who is able to give various delicious foods, fragrances, garlands, clothes, vehicles, houses, bedding, wealth, lamps, and medicine for illness. Giving away such things and distributing them to others is called material giving.
What is giving the Dharma?

It refers to extensively proclaiming the true Dharma for others, with goodness in the beginning, middle, and end, skillful in literary expression and meaning, pure and complete in the Dharma of pure conduct, enabling sentient beings to attain liberation upon hearing it from the dharmas of birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress. This is called giving the Dharma.
Among these two kinds of giving, material and Dharma, the giving of Dharma is the most supreme, excellent, and foremost.
It is like in the world, from cows comes milk, from milk comes curd, from curd comes butter, from butter comes ghee, and from ghee comes cream of ghee.
Among these various cow products, the cream of ghee is the most supreme, excellent, and foremost.
In the same way, among the two kinds of giving, material and Dharma, the giving of Dharma is the most supreme, excellent, and foremost.

Among the giving of Dharma, only the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, with perfect knowledge and conduct, the Well-gone One, knower of the world, incomparable leader of persons to be tamed, teacher of gods and humans, the Buddha, the BhagavÄn, can give the Dharma without error.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
Among the two kinds of giving, the giving of Dharma is the foremost,
Those who can practice the Dharma offering are the most venerable among the Well-Gone Ones.
In the field of receiving material offerings, the TathÄgata is the foremost.
Practicing material offerings is uncertain, but receiving the Dharma offering is for sentient beings.
Material offerings cause sentient beings to attain worldly peace and happiness;
The Dharma offering causes the recipients to ultimately realize nirvÄá¹‡a.
I heard this said by the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
There are two kinds of sacrifices.
What are the two?
First, material sacrifices;
Second, Dharma sacrifices.

Material sacrifices refer to a type of person who sacrifices various delicious foods, fragrances, garlands, clothes, vehicles, dwellings, bedding, wealth, and lamps. Such types are called material sacrifices.

As for the Dharma sacrifice, it refers to the ability to perform the sacrifice of sutras, geya, vyakarana, gatha, udana, itivrttaka, jataka, vaipulya, and adbhutadharma, expounding them in accordance with principle through innumerable approaches, establishing them, discerning and revealing them, which is called the Dharma sacrifice.
Among these two kinds of sacrifices, material and Dharma, the Dharma sacrifice is the most supreme, excellent, and foremost.

It is just as in the world, milk comes from cows, curds come from milk, butter comes from curds, ghee comes from butter, and the best essence comes from ghee. Among these various cow products, the best essence is the most supreme, excellent, and foremost.
In the same way, among the two kinds of sacrifices, material and Dharma, the Dharma sacrifice is the most supreme, excellent, and foremost.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Among those who perform the Dharma sacrifice, only the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the One of Perfect Knowledge and Conduct, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the World, the Incomparable Leader, the Trainer of Men, the Teacher of Gods and Men, the Buddha, the Blessed One, can perform the Dharma sacrifice without error.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning in verse, saying:
Among the two kinds of sacrifices, the Dharma sacrifice is the foremost.
Among those who perform the Dharma sacrifice, the Well-Gone One is the most honored.
In the field of receiving the sacrifice of wealth, the TathÄgata is the foremost.
Performing the sacrifice of wealth is uncertain, but receiving the Dharma sacrifice is for sentient beings.
The sacrifice of wealth enables sentient beings to attain worldly peace and happiness;
The Dharma sacrifice causes the recipient to ultimately realize nirvÄá¹‡a.
I heard this from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that
when practitioners gather together, they should do two things:
First, speaking the Dharma;
Second, silent meditation.
Because of speaking the Dharma, one can discern those with virtue;ğŸ”½Because of discerning virtue, one deeply respects and believes;
Because of deep respect and belief, one goes to them;
Because of going to them, one draws near and makes offerings;
Because of drawing near and making offerings, one seeks to hear the true Dharma;ğŸ”½Because of seeking to hear the Dharma, one focuses the ears without distraction;
Because the ears are undistracted, one listens to the true Dharma;ğŸ”½Because of listening to the true Dharma, one becomes proficient in the Dharma;
Because of proficiency in the Dharma, one is able to memorize the Dharma;ğŸ”½Because of memorizing the Dharma, one is able to contemplate the meaning;
When contemplating the meaning, one is able to carefully contemplate the Dharma;
When able to carefully contemplate the Dharma, one then gives rise to desire;
Having given rise to desire, one then attains power;
Having attained power, one is then able to weigh;
Because of weighing, one is then able to discern;
Because of being able to discern, one is able to awaken to the truth and then know for oneself:
My births are exhausted, the holy life has been established, what was to be done has been done, I will not receive another existence.
Because of silence, the mind becomes tranquil, pure, and bright, without blemish or fault, free from secondary afflictions, disciplined and workable, abiding immovable, and able to be drawn forth;
Because of being able to draw forth, one truly knows;
Because of truly knowing, one is able to be disgusted;ğŸ”½Because of being able to be disgusted, one is able to be free from desire;
Having already been free from desire, one attains liberation;
Having attained liberation, one knows for oneself:
I have attained liberation, my births are exhausted, the holy life has been established, what was to be done has been done, I will not receive another existence.
You bhiká¹£us should explain the supreme Dharma and understand the supreme Dharma.
If you are able to do so, then you will be called a true upholder of the sage's banner.
It is not through frivolous speech and discussion in assemblies that one can correctly understand the true nature of phenomena, cut off the defilements, and realize nirvana.
I always gather to proclaim the supreme Dharma and understand the supreme Dharma, therefore it is called the foremost acceptance of the banner of the sage.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
When practitioners gather, they should cultivate two things:
Silence and stillness, and speaking the true Dharma.
Because of speaking the true Dharma and silence and stillness,
One understands the true nature of phenomena and ultimately realizes nirvana.
You bhiká¹£us, if you speak of the supreme Dharma,
You will then be called true, accepting the banner of the great sage.
I always dwell in the midst of the assembly, proclaiming the illuminating Dharma,
Therefore it is called the foremost, accepting the banner of the great sage.
If one relies on the banner of the true Dharma, able to expound and practice,
One will quickly escape birth and death and reach ultimate nirvana.
I have heard these words from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!

If bhiká¹£us, when speaking, give rise to thoughts of desire, thoughts of anger, and thoughts of harm with improper attention, such bhiká¹£us are called those with much evil and those who practice laxly.

Because they are heading towards much evil as a means, they abandon the good yoke of abandoning and distancing themselves, and are negligent, lazy, and have inferior diligence, lose right mindfulness, have incorrect knowledge, have unstable minds and uncontrolled senses, have views that are not conducive to liberation, do not know how to correctly and truly discern liberation, head towards evil mÄras and unwholesome dharmas, are crushed by evil mÄras and unwholesome dharmas, and increase all evil and unwholesome dharmas.
If bhiká¹£us, during times of quiet meditation, give rise to improper thoughts, and so on, up to increasing all evil and unwholesome dharmas,
such bhiká¹£us will be scolded and criticized by all wise practitioners of pure conduct. I also will never praise them.
Even if such bhiká¹£us have gone forth and received full ordination, they are called people of evil wisdom who delight in existence and are foolish.
Therefore, you should train like this:
How can we skillfully eliminate improper thoughts and skillfully cultivate proper thoughts?
You bhiká¹£us should train like this.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
Whether speaking or in quiet meditation, if one indulges the faculties and creates evil,
not respectfully practicing my teachings, one is a foolish and ignorant person.
Therefore, you bhiká¹£us should cultivate non-negligence,
Abandoning improper attention, one should contemplate in accordance with reason.
If you are diligent, whether speaking or silent, without negligence,
Before long you will cross over birth and death and realize supreme nirvana.
I have heard thus:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!

If bhiká¹£us, when speaking, contemplate in accordance with reason, with thoughts of liberation, non-anger, and non-harming, such bhiká¹£us are called those with much goodness, those without negligence.

Because they are heading towards much goodness as a skillful means, they do not abandon the good yoke of abandonment and separation, are free from negligence, are vigorously diligent, have right mindfulness and right knowledge, their minds are concentrated and undisturbed, they carefully guard the sense faculties, have a view of liberation, are able to know liberation, and with right wisdom as it really is, they reject and turn away from the evil mÄra, evil unwholesome dharmas, subdue the evil mÄra, evil unwholesome dharmas, and reduce all evil unwholesome dharmas.
If bhiká¹£us, during silent meditation, direct their attention properly, and so on, up to reducing all evil and unwholesome states,
such bhiká¹£us will be praised by all wise practitioners of the holy life, and I will also always praise them.
Such bhiká¹£us are called true renunciants who have received full ordination, have great wisdom, do not delight in any existence, and are called wise ones.
Therefore, you should train thus:
How can we skillfully cultivate proper attention and skillfully eliminate improper attention?
You bhiká¹£us should train thus.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
Whether speaking or in silent meditation, do not let the faculties run wild and create evil,
Those who are able to respectfully practice my teachings are wise and intelligent people.
Cultivate thoughts of renunciation, as well as non-anger and non-harming,
There is correct view that leads to liberation, which can truly know;
It can subdue evil mÄras and all unwholesome dharmas,
Permanently cutting off all afflictions, and realizing ultimate nirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore, you bhiká¹£us should cultivate non-negligence,
And contemplate in accordance with principle, leaving behind improper thoughts.
If you are diligent, in speech and silence without negligence,
Before long you will cross over birth and death, and realize unsurpassed nirvÄá¹‡a.
I heard the World-Honored One say this:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
A bhiká¹£u in training has two kinds of power.
What are the two?
They are the power of investigation and the power of cultivation.
What is it for a bhiká¹£u to have the power of investigation?
Namely, a certain type of learned bhiká¹£u, when using various robes, food and drink, dwellings, bedding, and medicine for illness as provisions, all well considered, not using without consideration.
Not greatly longing for robes, food and drink, dwellings, bedding, medicine for illness, and other provisions that have not yet been obtained;
Not deeply attached to robes, food and drink, dwellings, bedding, medicine for illness, and other provisions that have already been obtained.

Able to endure cold, heat, hunger, thirst, wind, sun, mosquitoes, gadflies, snakes, scorpions, and other contacts; able to endure others' slander, insults, and other words; able to endure the intense, sharp, sour, painful, unbearable, life-robbing, near-death, difficult-to-cure suffering arising within the body; able to endure all the most difficult-to-endure matters in the world.
They are able to skillfully discern the three kinds of evil deeds of body, speech, and mind, and illuminate the undesirable results of suffering in the present life, future lives, and the afterlife.
They think like this:
I will definitely abandon the three kinds of evil deeds of body, speech, and mind, and I will definitely cultivate the three kinds of good deeds of body, speech, and mind.
They are able to correctly understand the faults of the three kinds of evil deeds and also correctly understand the merits of the three kinds of good deeds.
Having correctly understood this, they diligently abandon and cultivate the three kinds of evil deeds and good deeds, and cultivate their own bodies to make them pure and free from sinful dharmas.
This is called the first power of discernment for a trainee bhiká¹£u.
What is the power of cultivation for a bhiká¹£u?

Namely, a certain type of learned bhiká¹£u, all the mindfulness he attains is in accord with the factors of enlightenment and not in opposition to them; the discernment of dharmas, vigor, joy, lightness, concentration, and equanimity he attains are all in accord with the factors of enlightenment and not in opposition to them;

Cultivating the factor of enlightenment of mindfulness, all rely on disgust, all rely on separation, all rely on cessation, and turn towards letting go. Cultivating the factors of enlightenment of discernment of dharmas, vigor, joy, lightness, concentration, and equanimity, all rely on disgust, all rely on separation, all rely on cessation, and turn towards letting go.
This is called the power of subsequent cultivation of a learned bhiká¹£u.
These are called the two powers of a learned bhiká¹£u.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
The learned bhiká¹£us have, in brief, two kinds of powers,
Discernment and cultivation, able to subdue the army of MÄra.
Seeing the faults of evil, one is able to cut it off; knowing the virtues of the wonderful, one is able to cultivate it.
Being able to endure and contemplate is called the power of discernment.
Relying on disgust, cessation, and dedicating to abandonment,
And cultivating the seven factors of awakening is called the power of cultivation.
I heard these words from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
Because of the extinction of two kinds of dharmas, there is death.
What are the two dharmas?
First, karma;
Second, life.
Because of the exhaustion of karma and the exhaustion of life, one definitely dies.
When there is karma, at that time there is life;
When there is life, at that time there is karma.
Why is it so?

Because these two dharmas are always in union, never not in union. These two dharmas cannot be established, analyzed, separated, or scattered.ğŸ”½At that time when there is karma, at that time there is life;
At that time when there is life, at that time there is karma.
If there is karma, then there is life;
if there is life, then there is karma.
If there is no karma, then there is no life;
if there is no life, then there is no karma.
It is like a burning lamp, the flame and light arising together. If there is a flame, then there is light;
if there is light, then there is a flame.ğŸ”½If there is no flame, then there is no light;
if there is no light, then there is no flame.
Karma and life are also like this.ğŸ”½If there is karma, then there is life;
if there is life, then there is karma.ğŸ”½If there is no karma, then there is no life;
if there is no life, then there is no karma.
These two dharmas end and cease, thus there is death.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning in verse, saying:
The two dharmas always follow each other, namely karma and life,
If there is karma, there is also life; if there is no karma, there is also no life.
As long as life and karma have not been exhausted, sentient beings will not die;
If life and karma are exhausted, there is no doubt that consciousness will die.
I have heard these words from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
There are two kinds of practices that sentient beings in the world all engage in together.
What are the two?
First, the practice that leads to a short lifespan;
Second, the practice that leads to a long lifespan.
What is the practice that leads to a short lifespan?

It refers to a type of person who always delights in killing, is by nature violent, has blood on their hands, harms the lives of others, has no shame, has no compassion, and always engages in killing sentient beings, up to and including ants with broken legs. This is called the practice that leads to a short lifespan.
What is the practice that leads to a long lifespan?

There is a type of person who abstains from killing, abandons killing implements, is ashamed and compassionate, and never harms any being, even to the extent of not harming an ant with broken legs. This is called the practice that leads to a long life.
These are called the two kinds of practices that beings in the world all create together.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
The beings in the world roughly have two kinds of practices.
Due to the differences in the two practices, they experience short or long lives.
That is to say, those who always delight in killing, are violent and bloody-handed,
lack shame, embarrassment, and compassion, will undoubtedly experience a short life.
Those who always delight in abstaining from killing, abandon all killing implements,
have shame, embarrassment, and compassion, will undoubtedly experience a long life.
I heard this from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know:
The mind takes on its characteristics through two modes of activity.
What are the two?
The first is called the mode of activity of the object;
The second is called the mode of activity of attention.
All past, present, and future mind characteristics are due to these two modes of activity.

You bhiká¹£us should diligently take on the characteristics of the mind through these two modes of activity;ğŸ”½Having taken on the characteristics of the mind, you should skillfully direct your attention;
Having skillfully directed your attention, you should skillfully observe;
Having skillfully observed, you should skillfully abide;

Having skillfully abided, you should cultivate the immeasurables and harmlessness in accordance with the earth element, and you should cultivate the immeasurables and harmlessness in accordance with the water element, fire element, and wind element.
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!

It is like the earth element, which, if you place excrement, mucus, pus, blood, and other such pure and impure things in it, does not, in placing them there, ever violate or comply with, delight in or be sad about, or be high or low because of them.
In this way, you should set your mind to be the same as the earth element, and diligently cultivate it without limit or harm.

Having the same as the earth element, diligently cultivate it without limit or harm, even if you encounter various adverse and favorable conditions, your mind will be completely without discrimination or attachment, and will not be high or low because of these different conditions.

It is also like the water element, fire element, and wind element, which, if you place excrement, mucus, pus, blood, and other such pure and impure things in them, do not, in placing them there, ever violate or comply with, delight in or be sad about, or be high or low because of them.
In this way, one should make the mind the same as the water element, fire element, and wind element, diligently cultivating it without limit or harm.

Having made the mind the same as the water element, fire element, and wind element, diligently cultivating it without limit or harm, even when encountering various adverse and favorable conditions, the mind is completely free from discrimination and attachment, and is not affected by these different conditions, with the mind neither elated nor depressed.

By means of this concentration, the latent tendencies of grasping at 'I' and 'mine,' views, pride, and afflictions towards the body with consciousness and all external objects are well subdued and well eliminated.
The mind transcends both of them, free from all characteristics, peaceful and blissful, attaining good liberation.

All the good liberation of the mind and the good liberation of wisdom are contained within this, well subduing and well eliminating the latent tendencies of grasping at 'I' and 'mine,' views, and pride.
Their minds transcend those two kinds, free from all characteristics, tranquil and peaceful, and attain liberation.
They do not delight in gain, praise, fame, or pleasure;
They are not distressed by loss, slander, criticism, or suffering. This is called transcending the world's eight dharmas.
Their minds are equal, just like the earth, water, fire, and wind in the world, untainted by the world's eight dharmas.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
The mind is difficult to tame and restless, far-reaching with no second,
Able to correctly apply effort and take on characteristics, this is called worldly wisdom.
Having well taken on the characteristics of the mind, one further observes with intention,
Correctly mindful, abiding in the mind, diligently cultivating the same as the four elements.
Thus correctly abiding, able to abandon all desires,
In the eight worldly dharmas, they are called skillful and unstained.
I heard these words from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know:
There are two kinds of dharmas that, although always in conflict and never in harmony, are nevertheless uninterrupted in between.
What are the two?
Namely, birth and death.
It is like the light and darkness in the world, which, although always in conflict and never in harmony, are nevertheless uninterrupted in between.ğŸ”½When light appears, darkness disappears;
when darkness arises, light ceases.
Birth and death are also like this, always in conflict and never in harmony, yet uninterrupted in between.
When the dharma of birth exists, the dharma of death disappears;
when the dharma of death exists, the dharma of birth ceases.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
Just like light and darkness, although always in conflict,
Yet within these two dharmas, there has never been any interruption or deficiency.
Birth and death are also like this. Although they are always in conflict,
Yet within these two dharmas, there has never been any interruption or deficiency.
Born from the roots of ignorance, nourished by the water of craving,
As soon as one dies, birth continues, without any interruption in between.
I have heard these words from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know:
There are two kinds of death.
What are the two?
The first is the death of the undisciplined;
The second is the death of the disciplined.
What is meant by the death of the undisciplined?

It refers to foolish people, those without learning, and ordinary beings who have not yet been able to personally encounter the virtuous and have not yet been able to understand the Dharma of the virtuous. They are not yet self-disciplined in the Dharma of the virtuous.
They observe and see:
Form is precisely myself, form belongs to me, form is within me, I am within form.
They follow and observe:
Feeling is precisely me, feeling belongs to me, feeling is in me, I am in feeling.
They follow and observe:
Perception is precisely me, perception belongs to me, perception is in me, I am in perception.
They follow and observe:
Mental formations are precisely me, mental formations belong to me, mental formations are in me, I am in mental formations.
They follow and observe:
Consciousness is precisely me, consciousness belongs to me, consciousness is in me, I am in consciousness.
When the eye sees forms, it grasps at their characteristics and grasps at their details.

For this reason, one is unable to rightly recollect and guard the eye faculty while dwelling, and gives rise to craving and worry, so that there are immeasurable evil and unwholesome states that flow along with the mind, which cannot be dammed up.
One is unable to guard the eye faculty, and indulges in the eye faculty to engage with objects, craving the taste of forms, and is entangled and disturbed in the mind.

Because of this craving, one experiences suffering for a long time, experiences intense suffering, experiences the suffering of deprivation, increases the body of blood and cauldrons, increases the road of emptiness and wilderness, and goes back and forth in the realms of hell, animals, hungry ghosts, asuras, humans, and gods, experiencing various intense sufferings. All this is due to the lack of control over the eye faculty.

In this way, at times, having heard sounds with the ear, smelled scents with the nose, tasted flavors with the tongue, felt tactile objects with the body, and cognized mental objects with the mind, one grasps their characteristics and grasps their secondary marks.

Because of this, one is unable to maintain right mindfulness and guard the mind faculty, and thus craving and worry arise, and there is an immeasurable amount of evil and unwholesome dharmas that flow with the mind and cannot be blocked.
One is unable to guard the mind faculty, and indulges the mind faculty in engaging with objects, and is attached to the taste of dharmas that entangle and disturb the mind.

Because of this craving, one experiences suffering for a long time, experiences intense suffering, experiences the suffering of deprivation, increases the body of blood and pus, increases the path of emptiness, and goes back and forth in the realms of hell, animals, hungry ghosts, asuras, humans, and gods, experiencing various intense sufferings. All this is due to the lack of self-control of the mind faculty.
This is called the death of the undisciplined.
What is meant by the death of the disciplined?

It refers to the sages and noble disciples who have already been able to personally see virtuous and wise people, have already been able to understand the Dharma of virtuous and wise people, and have already disciplined themselves according to the Dharma of virtuous and wise people.
They do not follow the view that:
form is the self, form belongs to the self, form is in the self, or the self is in form.
They do not follow the view that:
feeling is the self, feeling belongs to the self, feeling is in the self, or the self is in feeling.
They do not follow the view that:
Consciousness is not the self, the self does not possess consciousness, consciousness is not in the self, the self is not in consciousness.
One should not view it in this way.
Formations are not the self, the self does not possess formations, formations are not in the self, the self is not in formations.
One should not view it in this way.
Consciousness is not the self, the self does not possess consciousness, consciousness is not in the self, the self is not in consciousness.
When the eye sees forms, one does not grasp at their characteristics or their details.

For this reason, one is able to rightly and well recollect and guard the eye faculty, and does not give rise to greed or sorrow. All the immeasurable evil and unwholesome dharmas that flow along with the mind can all be blocked.
One is able to guard the eye faculty well, and does not indulge the eye faculty in pursuing objects, nor does one greedily savor the taste of forms and allow them to entangle and disturb the mind.

Not giving rise to this craving, one does not experience suffering for a long time, does not experience intense suffering, does not experience suffering of privation, does not increase the body of blood and pus, does not increase the path of emptiness and desolation, and does not return to be born in the hells, animal realm, ghost realm, asura realm, human realm, or heavenly realm to experience various intense sufferings. All this is due to the good control of the eye faculty.

In this way, at times when one hears sounds with the ears, smells fragrances with the nose, tastes flavors with the tongue, feels tactile objects with the body, or cognizes dharmas with the mind, one does not grasp their characteristics or grasp their secondary marks.

By this cause and condition, one is able to properly and well recollect and guard the mind faculty, and does not give rise to craving or worry. The immeasurable evil and unwholesome dharmas that flow along with the mind are all able to be blocked.

With regard to the mind faculty, one is able to guard it well and not indulge the mind faculty in engaging with sense objects. One does not crave the taste of dharmas and become entangled and disturbed in the mind.

Not giving rise to this craving, one does not experience suffering for a long time, does not experience intense suffering, does not experience suffering of privation, does not increase the body of blood and pus, does not increase the path of emptiness and desolation, and does not return to be born in the hells, animal realm, ghost realm, asura realm, among humans and gods, to experience various intense sufferings. All this is due to the well-tamed mind faculty.
This is called dying in a tamed state.
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!ğŸ”½Those who die untamed sink into the immeasurable suffering of birth and death;
Those who die tamed transcend the immeasurable suffering of birth and death.
This is called the two kinds of death.
At that time, the World-Honored One summarized the meaning and spoke a verse, saying:
In brief, all sentient beings have two kinds of death,
Tamed and untamed, there is no third kind.
If one dies untamed, one will definitely in the various destinies
Passing through immeasurable eons.ğŸ”½Those who tame and die,
Will never fall into evil destinies,ğŸ”½In the realms of humans and gods,
They will be able to eternally end all suffering.
I have heard these words from the World-Honored One:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know!
All dharmas can be summarized into two types.
What are the two?
First, defiled;
Second, pure.
One should correctly contemplate the arising of dharmas due to a single dharma.
Why is it so?
If one can correctly guard a single dharma, then one can correctly guard all;
If one cannot guard a single dharma, then one cannot guard all.
What is the single dharma?
It refers to the mind of sentient beings.
If one cannot guard the mind, then one cannot guard bodily, verbal, and mental actions;
If one cannot protect one's bodily, verbal, and mental actions, then one's bodily, verbal, and mental actions will all be ruined;
because one's bodily, verbal, and mental actions are all ruined, one's mind will then be disturbed, defiled, and stained.
One whose mind is disturbed, defiled, and stained will have no way to correctly understand what is beneficial for oneself, beneficial for others, or beneficial for both;
one will have no way to correctly understand the meaning of good speech or the meaning of bad speech;
one will also have no way to realize the true wisdom and insight of a superior person.
Why is this?
Because the mind is disturbed, defiled, and stained.

It is like a pavilion in the world. If the central pillar is not well covered, then the rafters, beams, and walls will all be drenched by leaks. Because the rafters, beams, and walls are drenched by leaks, they will all be ruined.
